all_paragraphs: A horse-racing gambler, hoping to maximize his winnings, decides to create a computer program that will accurately predict the winner of a horse race based on the usual information (number of races recently won by each horse, betting odds for each horse, etc.). To create such a program, he asks a highly successful expert gambler to explain his betting strategy. Not surprisingly, the expert is unable to articulate a grand set of rules for selecting a horse. On the other hand, when presented with the data for a specific set of races, the expert has no trouble coming up with a “rule of thumb” for that set of races (such as, “Bet on the horse that has recently won the most races” or “Bet on the horse with the most favored odds”). Although such a rule of thumb, by itself, is obviously very rough and inaccurate, it is not unreasonable to expect it to provide predictions that are at least a little bit better than random guessing. Furthermore, by repeatedly asking the expert’s opinion on different collections of races, the gambler is able to extract many rules of thumb.
In order to use these rules of thumb to maximum advantage, there are two problems faced by the gambler:
First, how should he choose the collections of races presented to the expert so as to extract rules of thumb from the expert that will be the most useful?
Second, once he has collected many rules of thumb, how can they be combined into a single, highly accurate prediction rule?

Boosting refers to a general and provably effective method of producing a very accurate prediction rule by combining rough and moderately inaccurate rules of thumb in a manner similar to that suggested above.
The above excerpt was taken from the famous paper: Intro to Boosting, and I couldn’t have done a better job at introducing boosting to the uninitiated.

However, this article assumes familiarity with boosting and will just try to explain the math behind AdaBoost, hopefully, in simple steps. The concepts, often simple and beautiful gets lost in mathematical jargon. I had faced the same challenges while understanding the math and this is an attempt to consolidate my understanding while helping others on a similar journey.

The first line is pretty simple to understand, still, for the sake of completeness, I will describe it. It tells that assume there are m observations like x₁, x₂, x₃ .. xₘ these set of observations is called X , while the target variable is given by y₁, y₂, y₃ .. yₘ belonging to Y, where the targets are called {-1,+1} depending on the class of the target {Win/Loss}, {Positive/Negative}, etc.
In short, it describes the structure of the data set that we are feeding to the model.

Next, we will assign a weight to each of the observation, the idea is that there are few observations which are easy to classify while there are others which are difficult to classify for the classifier algorithm. We will adjust the weights after every iteration such that the the algorithm is forced to take a harder look at these difficult to classify observations.

But before going into all these, at the first iteration we have no clue as to which observations are difficult to classify and which ones are easy to classify so we will assign equal weight to each algorithm.
This is literally the iterative part of the algorithm, it states that you will run the algorithm T times, you can specify this value while running AdaBoost.

Great now that we understand αₜ we will calculate α₁.
Notice that models with low error rate will have higher values of αₜ and hence higher weight in the final output.
